The 10 Commandment

The **Jewish 10 Commandments**, also known as the **Ten Commandments** or **Decalogue**, are a set of ethical principles that, according to the Bible, were given to Moses by God on Mount Sinai. They are central to both Judaism and Christianity. Here they are:

##### 1. I am the Lord your God  
You shall have no other gods before Me.

##### 2. You shall not make for yourself a graven image  
Do not make or worship idols.

##### 3. You shall not take the name of the Lord your God in vain  
Do not misuse God's name or use it disrespectfully.

##### 4. Remember the Sabbath day and keep it holy  
Observe the Sabbath as a day of rest and worship.

##### 5. Honor your father and mother  
Respect and obey your parents.

##### 6. You shall not murder  
Respect the sanctity of human life.

##### 7. You shall not commit adultery  
Be faithful in marriage and relationships.

##### 8. You shall not steal  
Do not take what belongs to others.

##### 9. You shall not bear false witness against your neighbor  
Do not lie or give false testimony.

##### 10. You shall not covet  
Do not desire or be envious of what others have.

These commandments are foundational to Jewish ethics and law. They appear in the books of **Exodus 20:1–17** and **Deuteronomy 5:4–21**.
